author: liger1978
body:
Here is `$env:PSModulePath` on CentOS:

```
/home/user/.local/share/powershell/Modules:/usr/local/share/powershell/Modules:/opt/microsoft/powershell/6-preview/Modules
```

It would be nice if  `/usr/share/powershell/Modules` could be added to this list of directories on *nix systems so that modules can be installed using the OS package manager (e.g. rpm, deb, etc). Typically it is not good practice for these package managers to write to `/usr/local`.

comments.author: DHowett
comments.body:
This may be the maintainer's responsibility. They know better than PowerShell where the distribution-managed modules will be installed.

Where they can configure that depends on the user's login manager; _systemd-logind_ supports drop-in files in `/etc/environment.d`, which a powershell package could place per-distribution and standard shadow _login_ may get env vars from `/etc/environment` (because of _pam_env.so_, which is broadly enabled by default.)

Since anything that exists in `$Env:PSModulePath` before powershell loads seems to be combined with the user's local module path, this shouldn't present an integration issue.

comments.author: liger1978
comments.body: OK, well can this be add to the RHEL/CentOS RPMs that are distributed by Microsoft then?

title: Update $env:PSModulePath to include an OS package manager PowerShell module location
